title: The Coals of Restoration
subtitle: When the smell of failure becomes the aroma of forgiveness

key_verse.text: So when they had dined, Jesus saith to Simon Peter, Simon, son of Jonas, lovest thou me more than these? He saith unto him, Yea, Lord; thou knowest that I love thee. He saith unto him, Feed my lambs.

verses.text: As soon then as they were come to land, they saw a fire of coals there, and fish laid thereon, and bread.
So when they had dined, Jesus saith to Simon Peter, Simon, son of Jonas, lovest thou me more than these? He saith unto him, Yea, Lord; thou knowest that I love thee. He saith unto him, Feed my lambs.
He saith to him again the second time, Simon, son of Jonas, lovest thou me? He saith unto him, Yea, Lord; thou knowest that I love thee. He saith unto him, Feed my sheep.

He saith unto him the third time, Simon, son of Jonas, lovest thou me? Peter was grieved because he said unto him the third time, Lovest thou me? And he said unto him, Lord, thou knowest all things; thou knowest that I love thee. Jesus saith unto him, Feed my sheep.

Verily, verily, I say unto thee, When thou wast young, thou girdedst thyself, and walkedst whither thou wouldest: but when thou shalt be old, thou shalt stretch forth thy hands, and another shall gird thee, and carry thee whither thou wouldest not.
This spake he, signifying by what death he should glorify God. And when he had spoken this, he saith unto him, Follow me.

context_verses.text: And the servants and officers stood there, who had made a fire of coals; for it was cold: and they warmed themselves: and Peter stood with them, and warmed himself.

And Simon Peter stood and warmed himself... They said therefore unto him, Art not thou also one of his disciples? He denied it, and said, I am not... Peter then denied again: and immediately the cock crew.

cards.title: Two Fires, Two Destinies
cards.subtitle: The smell Peter never forgot
cards.content:
Imagine this:

You're standing on a beach. You just swam desperately toward your Lord after having denied Him. You're wet, ashamed, speechless.

And then... you smell SMOKE.

üî• THE FIRST FIRE (John 18:18):

'And the servants and officers stood there, who had made a FIRE OF COALS; for it was cold: and they warmed themselves: and Peter stood with them, and warmed himself.'

It was at that fire where Peter:
‚Ä¢ Denied Jesus the 1st time (v.17)
‚Ä¢ Denied Jesus the 2nd time (v.25)
‚Ä¢ Denied Jesus the 3rd time (v.27)

While Jesus was being interrogated inside, Peter was warming himself outside by the coals, swearing: 'I know him not.'

üî• THE SECOND FIRE (John 21:9):

'As soon then as they were come to land, they saw a FIRE OF COALS there, and fish laid thereon, and bread.'

üëÉ THE OLFACTORY CONNECTION:

Here's the detail most people miss:

The Greek word for 'fire of coals' in BOTH passages is the SAME:

üìñ ANTHRAKIAN (Strong G440: ·ºÄŒΩŒ∏œÅŒ±Œ∫ŒπŒ¨ŒΩ)

This word appears only TWICE in the entire Bible:
1. John 18:18 - The fire of betrayal
2. John 21:9 - The fire of restoration

üß† WHY THIS MATTERS:

The human brain connects smells with memories more than any other sense. When Peter smelled those coals on the beach, his mind immediately transported him to the High Priest's courtyard.

üíî JESUS' INTENTION:

Jesus did NOT use coals by accident. He could have:
‚Ä¢ Cooked the fish another way
‚Ä¢ Prepared only bread
‚Ä¢ Performed a miracle without cooking

But He deliberately lit COALS.

Why? To unearth the trauma and heal it at the root.

‚ú® THE MESSAGE:

Jesus takes you back to the place of your fall, not to condemn you, but to redeem it. The same smell that reminds you of your betrayal now becomes the aroma of breakfast with your King.
cards.revelation_key: Jesus doesn't avoid painful memories. He redeems them. The fire that burned you can become the fire that feeds you.

cards.title: Simon, Son of Jonas
cards.subtitle: Why Jesus doesn't call him 'Peter'
cards.content:
When Jesus begins the most important conversation of Peter's life, notice what He calls him:

'Simon, son of Jonas...' (v.15, 16, 17)

THREE TIMES He uses his old name. Why?

ü™® THE NAME HE LOST:

When Jesus met Simon, He gave him a NEW name:

'Thou art Simon... thou shalt be called Cephas, which is by interpretation, A STONE/PETER' (John 1:42)

Peter means 'ROCK.' It was a prophetic declaration of who he would become.

But that night by the fire, the 'rock' crumbled.

üíî PETER'S BOASTING:

Before his fall, Peter had said:

'Though all men shall be offended because of thee, yet will I NEVER be offended... Though I should die with thee, yet will I NOT deny thee' (Matthew 26:33-35)

Peter believed his love was superior to the other disciples'.

üìç BACK TO THE BEGINNING:

By calling him 'Simon, son of Jonas,' Jesus is taking him back:
‚Ä¢ To the man BEFORE the promise
‚Ä¢ To the man BEFORE the calling
‚Ä¢ To the man in his ORIGINAL state

Why? Because the 'Rock' had been broken. Jesus needs to rebuild him from the foundation.

üî® NOT PUNISHMENT, BUT RECONSTRUCTION:

Jesus isn't removing the name to shame him. He's saying:
'Simon, we're going to start over. The Rock I build this time won't be founded on your confidence in yourself, but on your honesty about your weakness.'

üéØ THE FIRST QUESTION:

'Simon, son of Jonas, lovest thou me MORE THAN THESE?'

Jesus reminds him of his boasting: 'Though ALL deny thee, I will not.'

Peter, now humbled, can no longer claim his love is superior.
cards.identity_statement: When your identity in Christ is broken by your failure, Jesus doesn't abandon you. He takes you back to the starting point to rebuild you on a firmer foundation: grace, not your strength.
cards.revelation_key: Jesus calls you by your 'old name' not to condemn you, but to rebuild your identity from honesty, not from presumption.

cards.title: Agapa≈ç vs Phile≈ç: The Descent of Love
cards.subtitle: When Jesus descends to your level
cards.content:
This conversation is surgical. Every word matters. And in the original Greek, there's a detail that COMPLETELY changes the meaning.

Greek has several words for 'love.' Here TWO appear:

üíé AGAPA≈å (Strong G25: ·ºÄŒ≥Œ±œÄŒ¨œâ):
‚Ä¢ Love of SACRIFICE
‚Ä¢ UNCONDITIONAL love
‚Ä¢ Love of DECISION, not feeling
‚Ä¢ The love with which God loves us

‚ù§Ô∏è PHILE≈å (Strong G5368: œÜŒπŒªŒ≠œâ):
‚Ä¢ Love of FRIENDSHIP
‚Ä¢ Love of AFFECTION
‚Ä¢ BROTHERLY, tender love
‚Ä¢ The love you feel for a close brother

üó£Ô∏è THE REAL CONVERSATION:

1Ô∏è‚É£ FIRST QUESTION (v.15):
Jesus: 'Lovest thou me (AGAPAS)?'
Peter: 'Thou knowest that I love (PHILE≈å) thee'

2Ô∏è‚É£ SECOND QUESTION (v.16):
Jesus: 'Lovest thou me (AGAPAS)?'
Peter: 'Thou knowest that I love (PHILE≈å) thee'

3Ô∏è‚É£ THIRD QUESTION (v.17):
Jesus: 'Lovest thou me (PHILEIS)?'
Peter: 'Thou knowest that I love (PHILE≈å) thee'

üíî DO YOU SEE WHAT HAPPENED?

In the first TWO questions:
‚Ä¢ Jesus asks for AGAPƒí (divine love)
‚Ä¢ Peter responds with PHILE≈å (human love)

Peter is saying: 'Lord, I no longer dare to say my love is like Yours. I failed. I can only tell You I love You like a very close friend, but I cannot claim perfect love.'

But in the THIRD question:
‚Ä¢ Jesus CHANGES His word
‚Ä¢ Jesus now asks: 'Lovest thou me (PHILEIS)?'

üò¢ WHY PETER WAS GRIEVED:

'Peter was grieved because he said unto him the third time, Lovest thou me?'

Not only because it was the third time. Peter was grieved because he realized:

'My Lord has had to LOWER His standard of love because I couldn't reach His.'

‚ú® THE DIVINE MARK:

Jesus DESCENDS to Peter's level. He says:
'Simon, if all you can give me today is the imperfect love of a failed friend, I TAKE IT. I bless it. And with THAT I restore you.'

Jesus doesn't wait for Peter to be perfect to give him ministry. He perfects Peter THROUGH his honesty.

greek_words.meaning: To love with divine, sacrificial, unconditional love
greek_words.revelation: Jesus asks for this love, not to reject you if you don't have it, but to show you the standard to which He will bring you.

greek_words.meaning: To love with friendship love, brotherly affection
greek_words.revelation: Jesus is willing to DESCEND to your level of imperfect love rather than leave you out of His purpose.

cards.revelation_key: Jesus doesn't reject your imperfect love. He takes it, blesses it, and transforms it. His grace descends to where you are to lift you to where He is.

cards.title: Three Questions, Three Tasks
cards.subtitle: From traitor to shepherd
cards.content:
After each confession of love, Jesus gives Peter a TASK. They're not the same. Each one increases in level:

ü•õ FIRST TASK (v.15):
'Feed (BOSK≈å) my lambs (ARNIA)'

üìñ Bosk≈ç (Strong G1006: Œ≤œåœÉŒ∫œâ) = To FEED, nourish, lead to pasture
üìñ Arnia (Strong G721: ·ºÄœÅŒΩŒØŒøŒΩ) = Small LAMBS, babies

Meaning: 'Feed the newborns. Give milk to those just starting. Care for the most vulnerable.'

üõ°Ô∏è SECOND TASK (v.16):
'Feed (POIMAIN≈å) my sheep (PROBATA)'

üìñ Poimain≈ç (Strong G4165: œÄŒøŒπŒºŒ±ŒØŒΩœâ) = To SHEPHERD (complete): guide, protect, govern, watch over
üìñ Probata (Strong G4263: œÄœÅœåŒ≤Œ±œÑŒøŒΩ) = Adult SHEEP

Meaning: 'Now don't just feed. GUIDE those who are already walking. Protect them from wolves. Govern the flock with wisdom.'

üçû THIRD TASK (v.17):
'Feed (BOSK≈å) my sheep (PROBATA)'

Meaning: 'Keep nourishing the entire flock until the end. Never stop feeding my people.'

üîë THE PATTERN:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Nourish those just starting (LAMBS)
2Ô∏è‚É£ Guide and protect those already walking (SHEEP)
3Ô∏è‚É£ Keep feeding everyone constantly (SHEEP)

üí° THE LEGAL RESTORATION:

Notice the structure:
‚Ä¢ 3 denials by the fire (John 18)
‚Ä¢ 3 confessions by the fire (John 21)
‚Ä¢ 3 tasks to erase the 3 betrayals

Jesus is making a LEGAL restoration. The record of guilt has been erased.

‚ù§Ô∏è THE BEAUTIFUL DETAIL:

Each time Jesus says 'MY lambs,' 'MY sheep.'

Jesus isn't giving up His flock. He's appointing Peter as His REPRESENTATIVE:

'Peter, these are MY sheep. I'm still the owner. But I'm entrusting you with what I love most. Care for them as I would care for them.'

‚ö° THE PREPARATION:

Before giving him these tasks, Jesus did something:

He fed them PHYSICALLY on the beach (v.12-13).

Then He tells Peter: 'Now you do the same SPIRITUALLY with others.'

scripture_connections.text: I am the good shepherd: the good shepherd giveth his life for the sheep
Feed the flock of God... neither as being lords over God's heritage, but being examples to the flock

cards.revelation_key: Jesus converts your failure into your ministry. The area where you fell most can become the area where you serve most, because now you serve from grace, not from presumption.

cards.title: The Cost of Restored Love
cards.subtitle: John 21:18-19 - From presumption to prophecy
cards.content:
After restoring Peter, Jesus reveals something striking:

‚ö†Ô∏è THE PROPHECY (v.18):

'Verily, verily, I say unto thee, When thou wast young, thou girdedst thyself, and walkedst whither thou wouldest: but when thou shalt be old, thou shalt stretch forth thy hands, and another shall gird thee, and carry thee whither thou wouldest not.'

‚úã 'STRETCH FORTH THY HANDS':

In the ancient world, this was a technical phrase for CRUCIFIXION. Stretching out the arms to be bound to the patibulum (the crossbeam).

Jesus is telling him: 'Peter, you will die crucified.'

üíî THE DIVINE IRONY:

Remember what Peter said BEFORE his denial:

'Lord, I am ready to go with thee, both into prison, and to death... I WILL LAY DOWN MY LIFE for thy sake' (John 13:37)

At that moment it was PRESUMPTION. Peter trusted in his own strength.

Now Jesus tells him: 'Now you WILL do it. Not by your strength, but because My love in you will carry you to that place.'

‚ú® 'GLORIFY GOD' (v.19):

'This spake he, signifying by what death he should glorify God.'

John sees Peter's death not as a tragedy, but as a way to GLORIFY (doxasei) God.

A martyr's death is the final proof that Christ is REAL.

üéØ THE CONTRAST:

BEFORE:
‚Ä¢ 'When thou wast young, thou walkedst whither thou wouldest'
‚Ä¢ Peter was impetuous, made his own decisions
‚Ä¢ Trusted in himself

AFTER:
‚Ä¢ 'Another shall gird thee, and carry thee whither thou wouldest not'
‚Ä¢ Peter is no longer directing his life
‚Ä¢ Christ is leading him, even to the cross

üë£ 'FOLLOW ME' (v.19):

Jesus ends with the SAME words He said to him at the beginning (Matthew 4:19):

'FOLLOW ME!'

üìñ Akolouthei (Strong G190: ·ºàŒ∫ŒøŒªŒøœçŒ∏ŒµŒπ) = Present imperative = 'KEEP FOLLOWING ME'

It's not a one-time call. It's a call to CONSTANCY:

'Peter, we've erased the past. I've given you a task. Now WALK behind me, step by step, until the end.'

üìú THE FULFILLMENT:

Historical tradition says Peter died in Rome, crucified.

He asked to be crucified UPSIDE DOWN, because he didn't feel worthy to die like his Lord.

That man we see today weeping on the beach, wet and ashamed, became the bravest leader in history.

Why? Because Jesus went to the ROOT.
cards.identity_statement: Your imperfect love today will be perfected by Christ until you're willing to give EVERYTHING. Not because you're strong, but because He is faithful.
cards.revelation_key: Jesus doesn't need you to be a spiritual superhero today. He takes your 'little,' your honesty, your tears, and HE HIMSELF grows it until you're capable of giving everything.

discovery_questions.question: What's the 'smell of coals' in your life? What sensory memory immediately transports you to your moment of greatest shame or failure? Have you considered that Jesus wants to redeem that memory, not avoid it?

Peter could only say 'I love thee (phile≈ç)' instead of 'I love thee (agapa≈ç).' Are you being honest with Jesus about the REAL state of your love for Him, or are you pretending a perfect love you don't have?
Jesus LOWERED His word from agapa≈ç to phile≈ç to meet Peter. Do you believe Jesus is willing to descend to where YOU are to lift you up? Or do you feel you must 'climb up' first before approaching?
Is there an area where you failed most that Jesus might be wanting to convert into your area of greatest service? Are you willing to serve from grace, not from presumption?
Peter said: 'Lord, thou knowest ALL THINGS; thou knowest that I love thee.' Are you willing to appeal to Jesus' omniscience? He sees your heart beyond your errors.

prayer.title: Prayer of Restoration
prayer.content:
Jesus, today I see myself standing before You like Peter: wet, ashamed, speechless.

And I smell the coals. That memory that transports me to my moment of denial, of betrayal, of failure.

But now I understand: You didn't light those coals to condemn me. You lit them to REDEEM that moment.

Thank You that You don't call me by my broken identity to shame me, but to REBUILD me from a firmer foundation.

Lord, I cannot tell You my love is perfect. Like Peter, I can only say: 'Thou knowest ALL THINGS. Thou seest my heart beyond my errors. Thou knowest that I love thee, though imperfectly.'

And if You are willing to DESCEND to my level of imperfect love, I surrender. Take it. Bless it. Transform it.

Give me a task, Lord. Convert my failure into my ministry. Use the area where I fell most to serve others from grace.

And as You said to Peter: 'FOLLOW ME!', I say to You today: Here I am. Step by step. Until the end.

In the name of the One who restores me by the fire: Jesus. Amen.
